repository.title: Introduction to PMBOK 7
repository.content: The PMBOK Guide 7th Edition represents a major shift from process-based to principle-based project management. It emphasizes value delivery and outcomes over rigid processes.

repository.title: The 12 Project Management Principles
repository.content: PMBOK 7 introduces 12 fundamental principles that guide project manager behavior and decision-making, including stewardship, team, stakeholder, value, systems thinking, leadership, tailoring, quality, complexity, risk, adaptability, and change.

repository.title: Performance Domains Overview
repository.content: The eight performance domains are: Stakeholders, Team, Development Approach and Life Cycle, Planning, Project Work, Delivery, Measurement, and Uncertainty. These represent interconnected areas of focus.

repository.title: Stakeholder Performance Domain
repository.content: This domain addresses activities and functions associated with stakeholders. Effective stakeholder engagement is critical to project success and involves understanding needs, expectations, and managing relationships.

repository.title: Team Performance Domain
repository.content: Focuses on activities related to the people responsible for producing project deliverables. Covers team culture, leadership, high-performing teams, and creating an environment of trust and collaboration.

repository.title: Development Approach Performance Domain
repository.content: Addresses the development approach of the project, including predictive, adaptive, and hybrid approaches.

repository.title: Planning Performance Domain
repository.content: Addresses planning activities including estimating, scheduling, budgeting, and coordination. Planning is iterative throughout the project and adapts to changing conditions.

repository.title: Uncertainty Performance Domain (Risk Management)
repository.content: Deals with uncertainty, ambiguity, and risk throughout the project. Includes both threats (negative risks) and opportunities (positive risks). Emphasizes proactive risk management and response strategies.

repository.title: Delivery Performance Domain
repository.content: Focuses on delivering the scope and quality expected by stakeholders. Covers requirements management, scope management, and ensuring deliverables meet quality standards.

repository.title: Measurement Performance Domain
repository.content: Addresses project performance assessment and measurement. Includes establishing baselines, tracking progress, and using metrics to support decision-making.

repository.title: Tailoring Project Management
repository.content: Extensive guidance on adapting project management approaches to fit the specific context, including consideration of development approach (predictive, adaptive, hybrid), governance, and organizational culture.

repository.title: Introduction to PRINCE2
repository.content: PRINCE2 (PRojects IN Controlled Environments) is a process-based method providing a structured approach to project management with defined organization, roles, and procedures.

repository.title: The 7 PRINCE2 Principles
repository.content: The seven principles are: Continued Business Justification, Learn from Experience, Defined Roles and Responsibilities, Manage by Stages, Manage by Exception, Focus on Products, and Tailor to Suit the Project Environment.

repository.title: The 7 PRINCE2 Themes
repository.content: The seven themes are aspects of project management that must be addressed continually: Business Case, Organization, Quality, Plans, Risk, Change, and Progress.

repository.title: Organization Theme
repository.content: Defines the project management team structure with clear roles and responsibilities. Key roles include Project Board (Executive, Senior User, Senior Supplier), Project Manager, and Team Manager.

repository.title: Risk Theme
repository.content: Provides an approach to managing uncertainty. Includes Risk Management Strategy, Risk Register, and procedures for identifying, assessing, and controlling risks throughout the project.

repository.title: Managing by Stages
repository.content: Projects are planned, monitored, and controlled on a stage-by-stage basis. Each stage requires authorization from the Project Board, providing control points for decision-making.

repository.title: Product-Based Planning
repository.content: PRINCE2's unique approach focuses on defining and delivering products (deliverables) rather than activities. Includes Product Description, Product Breakdown Structure, and Product Flow Diagram.

repository.title: Business Case Theme
repository.content: The Business Case is the key document that justifies the project investment. It is created at the start, maintained throughout, and verified at closure to ensure continued justification.

repository.title: Closing a Project Process
repository.content: The final PRINCE2 process covering project closure activities, including verification of deliverables, benefits realization plan, lessons learned, and formal project closure.

repository.title: ISO 21500 Introduction
repository.content: ISO 21500 provides high-level guidance on concepts and processes for project, programme, and portfolio management. It is applicable to any type of organization and any type of project.

repository.title: Context and Concepts
repository.content: Establishes the context of project management within organizations, including relationships between projects, programmes, portfolios, and organizational strategy.

repository.title: Governance Framework
repository.content: Describes the governance structure for projects, including organizational roles, oversight, and decision-making processes that align projects with organizational objectives.

repository.title: ISO 21502 Introduction
repository.content: ISO 21502 provides detailed guidance on project management processes, expanding on the concepts introduced in ISO 21500 with practical implementation guidance.

repository.title: Stakeholder Management Process
repository.content: Covers identification, analysis, and engagement of stakeholders throughout the project lifecycle. Emphasizes understanding stakeholder needs, expectations, and influence.

repository.title: Risk Management Process
repository.content: Describes systematic approach to managing risks including context establishment, risk assessment (identification, analysis, evaluation), risk treatment, and monitoring.

repository.title: Quality Management Process
repository.content: Establishes processes for planning, assurance, and control of quality throughout the project. Ensures deliverables meet defined requirements and fitness for purpose.

repository.title: Planning Processes
repository.content: Comprehensive guidance on project planning including scope definition, schedule development, resource allocation, cost estimation, and integrated planning.

repository.title: Project Closure Process
repository.content: Formal closure activities including deliverable verification, administrative closure, contract closure, and knowledge transfer. Ensures proper project conclusion.

pmbok.title: Principles-based Standard
pmbok.description: PMBOK 7: Principles-based standard (12 principles) + eight Project Performance Domains; systems view and outcomes/value focus. Emphasizes tailoring and models/methods/artifacts.
keyPoints: Flexible models, methods, and artifacts catalog

prince2.title: Method-based Approach
prince2.description: Method-based (integrated elements = Principles, Practices, Processes) with a product-focused planning approach, explicit roles (Project Board, Executive, Senior User/Supplier) and stage-based control.
keyPoints: Five integrated elements: Principles, People, Practices, Processes, Context
Seven defined processes from start to close
Explicit roles and responsibilities (Project Board structure)

iso.title: High-level Process/Practice Approach
iso.description: ISO 21500 gives context/concepts; ISO 21502 provides guidance and detailed management practices (clauses 7.x cover planning, risk, scope, quality, procurement, etc.). ISO takes a high-level process/practice approach aligned to organizational governance.

similarities: All three require explicit governance, role clarity, planning, risk and change management
Stakeholder engagement emphasized across all standards
differences: PMBOK 7 is principles + performance-domain oriented (outcomes-focused)
PRINCE2 is a prescriptive method with defined practices/processes and named roles
ISO combines context (21500) with practice guidance (21502) and is intentionally neutral/adoptable
PMBOK emphasizes tailoring and flexibility most
PRINCE2 provides most structured process model
ISO offers most generic, internationally applicable framework
recommendations: Use PMBOK for flexible, principle-based guidance adaptable to any methodology
Adopt PRINCE2 for structured, repeatable projects requiring clear governance
Apply ISO for international standardization and organizational consistency
Consider hybrid approaches combining strengths of each
Match framework choice to organizational culture and project context

pmbok.title: Risk Management - Uncertainty Performance Domain
pmbok.description: PMBOK 7 treats risk within the Uncertainty Performance Domain, emphasizing both threats and opportunities. It takes a comprehensive view of uncertainty management throughout the project.
keyPoints: Individual project risks and overall project risk addressed
Quantitative analysis techniques (Monte Carlo, decision trees) extensively covered
Risk response strategies: escalate, avoid, transfer, mitigate, accept, exploit, share, enhance
Continuous risk monitoring integrated into project work
Emphasis on risk attitude and risk thresholds

prince2.title: Risk Theme
prince2.description: PRINCE2 approaches risk as one of seven themes requiring continuous attention. It provides structured procedures and documentation for risk management with clear governance.
keyPoints: Risk Management Strategy defines the approach
Risk Register maintained as central artifact
Risk budget allocated for risk responses
Risk tolerance levels defined by Project Board
Defined risk management roles and responsibilities

iso.title: Risk Management Process
iso.description: ISO 21502 defines risk management as a process aligned with ISO 31000 risk management standard, providing systematic approach applicable across all project types.
keyPoints: Risk treatment planning aligned with organizational risk appetite
Monitoring and review as continuous activities

similarities: All three standards recognize risk as encompassing both threats and opportunities
Continuous monitoring and review emphasized across all frameworks
Risk identification and assessment are foundational steps in all approaches
All recognize importance of stakeholder risk attitude and tolerance
Integration of risk management throughout project lifecycle
differences: PMBOK provides most extensive quantitative analysis techniques and tools
PRINCE2 has most structured governance with Risk Theme and defined roles
ISO provides most generic framework aligned with ISO 31000, suitable for any context
PRINCE2 emphasizes risk budget as distinct concept
PMBOK distinguishes between individual and overall project risk more explicitly
recommendations: Use PMBOK quantitative techniques for large, complex projects requiring detailed analysis
Adopt PRINCE2 governance structure for organizations needing clear risk accountability
Apply ISO framework for international projects or organizations seeking ISO alignment
Consider hybrid approach: PRINCE2 governance + PMBOK analysis techniques
Tailor based on project size, complexity, and organizational maturity

pmbok.title: Stakeholder Performance Domain
pmbok.description: PMBOK 7 dedicates an entire performance domain to stakeholders, recognizing their critical importance. Emphasizes continuous engagement and relationship building throughout the project.
keyPoints: Stakeholder analysis using power/interest grids and influence diagrams
Engagement assessment matrix (Unaware, Resistant, Neutral, Supportive, Leading)
Communication strategies tailored to stakeholder needs and preferences
Building trust and effective relationships as primary focus
Integration with other performance domains (Team, Planning, Delivery)

prince2.title: Communication Management and Organization Theme
prince2.description: PRINCE2 integrates stakeholder management within its Organization Theme and Communication Management Approach, with predefined roles for key stakeholders.
keyPoints: Defined stakeholder roles: Executive, Senior User, Senior Supplier
Regular stakeholder reviews at stage boundaries
Product-based planning ensures stakeholder focus on deliverables
Project Board provides senior stakeholder governance
Clear escalation paths for stakeholder issues

iso.title: Stakeholder Management Process
iso.description: ISO 21502 defines stakeholder management as a distinct process, providing systematic approach to identification, analysis, and engagement of interested parties.
keyPoints: Engagement planning based on stakeholder analysis

similarities: All emphasize early stakeholder identification as critical success factor
Continuous engagement throughout project lifecycle is universal theme
Analysis of stakeholder power, interest, and influence is common
Regular communication and updates to stakeholders recognized by all
Managing expectations is key objective across all standards
differences: PMBOK has most comprehensive engagement strategies and techniques
PRINCE2 has most prescriptive approach with predefined roles
ISO provides most generic, adaptable framework
PMBOK Engagement Assessment Matrix is unique tool
PRINCE2 Project Board structure is distinctive governance model
recommendations: Use PMBOK engagement assessment matrix for complex stakeholder landscapes
Adopt PRINCE2 role definitions for clarity in governance and accountability
Apply ISO systematic approach for consistency across project portfolio
Consider PRINCE2 stage gates for formal stakeholder approval points
Tailor engagement intensity based on stakeholder analysis from any framework

pmbok.title: Planning Performance Domain
pmbok.description: PMBOK 7 views planning as an iterative performance domain that occurs throughout the project, not just at the beginning. Emphasizes adaptive planning and continuous refinement.
keyPoints: Iterative and progressive elaboration of plans
Integration with all other performance domains

prince2.title: Plans Theme and Product-Based Planning
prince2.description: PRINCE2 uses product-based planning approach, focusing on what needs to be delivered rather than activities. Plans exist at multiple levels (Project, Stage, Team).
keyPoints: Product-based planning: define products first, then activities
Product Breakdown Structure (PBS) and Product Flow Diagram
Three levels: Project Plan, Stage Plan, Team Plan

iso.title: Planning Processes
iso.description: ISO 21502 covers planning across multiple processes including scope, schedule, resource, and cost. Provides systematic approach applicable to any project type.
keyPoints: Scope definition and Work Breakdown Structure
Rolling wave planning for uncertain environments

similarities: All recognize planning as continuous throughout project lifecycle
Work breakdown structures (WBS/PBS) are foundational concepts
Integration of scope, schedule, and cost is universal
All support adaptive approaches for uncertain environments
differences: PRINCE2 product-based approach is unique, focusing on deliverables first
PMBOK provides most extensive estimating and scheduling techniques
PRINCE2 has most structured approach with three plan levels
ISO provides most generic framework without prescriptive methods
PRINCE2 stage-based planning with gates is distinctive
recommendations: Use PRINCE2 product-based planning for deliverable-focused projects
Apply PMBOK techniques for detailed scheduling and cost analysis
Consider ISO approach for standardization across diverse project types
Combine PRINCE2 stage planning with PMBOK estimation techniques
Tailor planning detail to project complexity and uncertainty

pmbok.title: Quality within Delivery Performance Domain
pmbok.description: PMBOK 7 integrates quality within the Delivery Performance Domain, emphasizing that quality must be built into processes and deliverables, not inspected in.
keyPoints: Quality integrated throughout project, not separate process
Quality standards and metrics defined early

prince2.title: Quality Theme
prince2.description: PRINCE2 dedicates a theme to quality, with structured approach including Quality Management Strategy and quality review technique for product validation.
keyPoints: Quality review technique for formal validation

iso.title: Quality Management Process
iso.description: ISO 21502 defines quality management process aligned with ISO 9001 quality management principles, covering planning, assurance, and control.
keyPoints: Quality planning defines standards and criteria
Quality assurance ensures processes are followed
Fitness for purpose as key criterion

similarities: All emphasize quality planning at project outset
Prevention rather than inspection is universal principle
All include validation of deliverables against criteria
differences: PRINCE2 has most structured approach with Quality Theme and formal reviews
ISO most closely aligned with quality management standards (ISO 9001)
PMBOK integrates quality most fully into overall delivery approach
PRINCE2 Product Descriptions provide most detailed quality specifications
ISO distinguishes most clearly between assurance and control
recommendations: Use PRINCE2 quality reviews for formal product validation
Apply ISO approach for ISO 9001 certified organizations
Adopt PMBOK integrated approach for agile/adaptive projects
Combine PRINCE2 Product Descriptions with ISO quality processes
Tailor formality of quality processes to project risk and complexity

pmbok.title: Governance within Project System
pmbok.description: PMBOK 7 addresses governance as part of the project system and organizational context, with less prescriptive structure than PRINCE2.
keyPoints: Project manager operates within governance structure

prince2.title: Organization Theme and Project Board
prince2.description: PRINCE2 provides highly structured governance with defined Project Board (Executive, Senior User, Senior Supplier) and management by exception principle.
keyPoints: Project Board provides governance and direction
Clear separation of responsibilities (Board vs PM)
Management by exception with defined tolerances
Stage gates for decision-making and authorization

iso.title: Governance Framework
iso.description: ISO 21502 describe governance structure within organizational context, emphasizing alignment with organizational objectives and decision-making processes.

similarities: All recognize need for clear governance structure
Decision rights and accountability are universal themes
differences: PRINCE2 provides most prescriptive governance model
PRINCE2 management by exception principle is unique
PMBOK allows most flexibility for organizational adaptation
PRINCE2 Project Board structure is highly defined
ISO provides highest-level principles without prescription
recommendations: Adopt PRINCE2 governance model for clear accountability
Use PRINCE2 stage gates for formal decision points
Apply ISO principles for portfolio-level governance
Tailor PRINCE2 Project Board to organizational context
Use management by exception to empower project managers

pmbok.title: Scope within Delivery Performance Domain
pmbok.description: PMBOK 7 focuses on outcomes and deliverables inside performance domains; scope is controlled within planning and project work.
keyPoints: Scope controlled within planning and project work domains
Focus on delivering value rather than just scope
Adaptive scope management for changing environments

prince2.title: Product-Based Planning
prince2.description: PRINCE2 is very product-focused with product descriptions driving scope, quality, and acceptance. Product Breakdown Structure and Product Flow Diagrams are core techniques.
keyPoints: Product descriptions drive scope, quality, acceptance
Product Breakdown Structure (PBS) as core technique

iso.title: Scope Management Practice
iso.description: ISO defines scope management as a discrete practice (7.4) — define, control, confirm scope delivery.

similarities: All require formal definition, control and confirmation of scope/deliverables
Work breakdown structures (WBS/PBS) are foundational concepts
Change control processes linked to scope management
differences: PRINCE2's explicit 'product' artifacts are unique in their centrality to planning and acceptance
PMBOK is more outcome/value oriented
ISO lays out standard processes for scope management
PRINCE2 Product Descriptions provide most detailed specifications
PMBOK integrates scope most fully into overall delivery approach
recommendations: Use PRINCE2 product-based planning for deliverable-focused projects
Apply PMBOK approach for outcome-driven, value-focused projects
Adopt ISO systematic approach for standardization across portfolio
Combine PRINCE2 Product Descriptions with PMBOK value focus
Tailor scope formality to project complexity and risk

pmbok.title: Change Management across Domains
pmbok.description: PMBOK 7 addresses change across planning and project work; tailoring determines specific control mechanisms.
keyPoints: Focus on adapting to change rather than resisting
Change as part of uncertainty management

prince2.title: Issues & Change Control Practice
prince2.description: PRINCE2 has a dedicated Issues & change control practice with change proposals, issue registers, and formal process for assessing/deciding on changes with clear responsibilities.
keyPoints: Clear roles and responsibilities for change

iso.title: Change Control Guidance
iso.description: ISO provides change control guidance (7.10) — establish framework, identify and assess change requests, plan implementation and closure.
keyPoints: Linkage to business case and objectives

similarities: Linkage to business case and plan adjustments
differences: PRINCE2 provides detailed roles and templates for issues/change handling
PMBOK leaves the specific mechanism to tailoring and the project's chosen approach
ISO provides clause-level steps to adopt
PRINCE2 combines issue and change management in single practice
PMBOK emphasizes adaptability over formal process
recommendations: Use PRINCE2 formal process for projects requiring strict governance
Apply PMBOK flexible approach for agile/adaptive projects
Adopt ISO framework for organizational standardization
Combine PRINCE2 templates with PMBOK adaptability
Tailor change control rigor to project risk level

pmbok.title: Value Delivery System
pmbok.description: PMBOK 7 focuses on value delivery and outcomes (system for value delivery); business-case thinking embedded in principles.
keyPoints: System for value delivery as holistic concept
Business case thinking embedded in principles
Focus on outcomes and benefits realization
Value as guiding principle for decisions

prince2.title: Business Case Practice
prince2.description: Business Case practice is central in PRINCE2; evolves through life cycle and is the basis for continued justification of the project.
keyPoints: Clear investment appraisal and benefits forecast

iso.title: Benefits Management Practice
iso.description: ISO provides benefits management practice (7.3) — identify, analyse, monitor, maintain benefits in alignment with strategy.

similarities: Business case / benefits must be defined, monitored and used to justify/terminate projects
All require ongoing justification for project continuation
differences: PRINCE2's lifecycle explicitly ties business case updates to stage boundaries and approvals
PMBOK treats benefits as part of the overall value-delivery system
ISO provides structured benefit management activities
PRINCE2 Business Case is most central to governance
PMBOK has broadest value delivery perspective
recommendations: Use PRINCE2 approach for projects requiring strict business justification
Apply PMBOK value delivery system for strategic initiatives
Adopt ISO structured approach for portfolio-level benefits tracking
Combine PRINCE2 Business Case rigor with PMBOK value focus
Regular benefits reviews regardless of chosen framework

pmbok.title: Communication across Domains
pmbok.description: Communication integrated across Planning & Project Work domains; emphasizes adapting to cadence and stakeholders.
keyPoints: Adaptive to delivery cadence and stakeholder needs
Emphasis on effective rather than excessive communication

prince2.title: Communication in Organizing and Plans
prince2.description: Communications integrated into Organizing and Plans practices; includes standard management products (highlight reports, checkpoint reports).

iso.title: Communication Management Practice
iso.description: ISO provides communication management practice (7.13) — plan, distribute, monitor impact.

similarities: Plan communications, select formats/cadence, monitor impact
differences: PRINCE2 offers a set of named report types and templates
PMBOK provides models and tailoring guidance
ISO provides standard process steps for planning and reporting
PRINCE2 has most prescriptive reporting structure
PMBOK emphasizes communication adaptability most
recommendations: Use PRINCE2 templates for structured reporting environments
Apply PMBOK flexible approach for diverse stakeholder groups
Adopt ISO framework for organizational communication standards
Combine PRINCE2 report types with PMBOK tailoring
Match communication formality to governance requirements

pmbok.title: Procurement in Planning & Project Work
pmbok.description: Procurement appears as part of Planning performance domain and Project Work considerations.
keyPoints: Focus on procurement processes within project context

prince2.title: Supplier Management
prince2.description: Supplier side is formalized (Senior Supplier role); procurement aspects integrated into organizing, plans and quality practices.
keyPoints: Senior Supplier role on Project Board

iso.title: Procurement Management Practice
iso.description: ISO provides procurement management practice (7.17) — plan procurement, evaluate/select suppliers, administer and close contracts.

similarities: Plan → select → administer → close lifecycle; alignment with project objectives
differences: PRINCE2's governance/role model assigns formal supplier representation and assurance roles
PMBOK focuses on procurement processes within the project context
ISO prescribes clause-level procurement steps
PRINCE2 integrates supplier most deeply into governance
ISO provides most structured procurement process
recommendations: Use PRINCE2 approach for projects with significant supplier dependencies
Apply PMBOK processes for diverse procurement scenarios
Adopt ISO framework for organizational procurement standardization
Use PRINCE2 Senior Supplier role for governance clarity
Tailor procurement formality to contract value and risk

pmbok.title: Learning Throughout Project
pmbok.description: Learning throughout the project; measurement and feedback (Measurement domain) and PMIstandards+ for ongoing practices.

prince2.title: Learn from Experience Principle
prince2.description: Principle 'Learn from experience' and explicit techniques to capture lessons and feed them into tailoring and future projects.

iso.title: Lessons Learned Practice
iso.description: ISO includes lessons learned as a practice (7.18) — identify, disseminate lessons.

similarities: Capture, disseminate and apply lessons to improve future projects and tailoring choices
differences: PRINCE2 makes learning a core principle
PMBOK integrates learning most fully with measurement
ISO treats lessons as discrete practice
PRINCE2 has most formal lessons documentation (Lessons Log)
PMBOK emphasizes continuous learning most
recommendations: Use PRINCE2 Lessons Log for structured capture
Apply PMBOK continuous learning approach for adaptive projects
Adopt ISO framework for organizational knowledge management
Regular lessons sessions regardless of methodology
Create searchable lessons repository for organization

pmbok.title: Measurement & Uncertainty Domains
pmbok.description: Dedicated Measurement domain and Uncertainty domain (includes risk, complexity, ambiguity). Emphasizes outcomes-based measures.
keyPoints: Uncertainty domain for risk, complexity, ambiguity

prince2.title: Progress Practice with Tolerances
prince2.description: Progress practice with tolerance reporting, highlight/exception reports and metrics for stage control.

iso.title: Reporting and Monitoring
iso.description: ISO provides reporting (7.15) and guidance for monitoring project performance and reporting outputs.

similarities: Define what to measure, use measures for decision-making and governance, handle uncertainty explicitly
Multiple measurement dimensions (time, cost, scope, quality)
differences: PMBOK provides a performance-domain view and wider set of measures
PRINCE2 prescribes management products/reports and tolerances for exception handling
ISO maps reporting to standardized processes
PRINCE2 tolerance mechanism is unique
PMBOK integrates measurement most comprehensively
recommendations: Use PRINCE2 tolerance approach for clear escalation triggers
Apply PMBOK measurement domain for comprehensive performance view
Adopt ISO framework for standardized reporting
Combine PRINCE2 exception reporting with PMBOK metrics
Tailor measurement frequency to project pace and risk

pmbok.title: Dedicated Tailoring Section
pmbok.description: PMBOK 7 has a dedicated Tailoring section; tailoring driven by principles, organizational values and project context; recommends PMIstandards+ for context-specific practices.
keyPoints: Tailoring driven by principles and context

prince2.title: Tailor to Suit the Project Principle
prince2.description: Explicit principle 'Tailor to suit the project'; tailoring decisions captured in initiation docs and approved by Project Board; practical guidance on what/how to tailor.
keyPoints: Practical guidance on what to tailor
Examples of tailoring for different contexts

iso.title: Adaptation to Context
iso.description: ISO emphasizes selecting approaches based on organizational/contextual considerations; ISO 21502 advises on how to adapt management practices to project context.

similarities: All require tailoring to project size, complexity, delivery method, risk, and organizational environment
Context assessment as foundation for tailoring
differences: PRINCE2 expects formal tailoring decisions to be approved by governance (Project Board) and captured in initiation documentation
PMBOK focuses on tailoring guided by principles and provides a catalog of models/methods (less prescriptive about approval steps)
ISO focuses on organizational selection criteria and alignment; less prescriptive about specific approval gates (left to organizational practice)
PMBOK has most extensive tailoring guidance
PRINCE2 has most formal tailoring approval process
recommendations: Use PRINCE2 formal approval for tailoring in governed environments
Apply PMBOK principle-based tailoring for flexible adaptation
Adopt ISO approach for organizational consistency
Document tailoring rationale regardless of methodology
Regular review of tailoring effectiveness

similarities.description: All three standards recognize that projects progress through distinct phases from initiation to closure, though terminology and structure differ.
Systematic identification, ongoing engagement, and use of stakeholder analysis to inform decisions. All emphasize continuous alignment with stakeholders.
All require identification, assessment (probability & impact), assignment of owners, planned responses, monitoring and communication for risk management.
Plan → assure → control cycles. All standards integrate quality into project lifecycle rather than as a separate afterthought.
All require tailoring to project size, complexity, delivery method, risk, and organizational environment.
Progressive elaboration, baseline and control, and alignment of plans with the business case throughout the project.
All emphasize capturing and applying lessons learned to improve future project performance.
Business case / benefits must be defined, monitored and used to justify/terminate projects throughout their lifecycle.
Plan communications, select formats/cadence, and monitor impact. All ensure systematic communication with stakeholders.
Plan → select → administer → close lifecycle with alignment to project objectives.
All require formal definition, control and confirmation of scope/deliverables.
Formal request/assessment/approval/implementation/closure lifecycle for changes. Linkage to business case and plan adjustments.
Need for defined accountability, escalation routes, and oversight. All require explicit governance structures.
Define what to measure, use measures for decision-making and governance, handle uncertainty explicitly.

standards.approach: Principles-based standard (12 principles) + eight Project Performance Domains. Systems view and outcomes/value focus. Emphasizes tailoring and models/methods/artifacts.
Method-based (integrated elements = Principles, Practices, Processes) with product-focused planning, explicit roles (Project Board, Executive, Senior User/Supplier) and stage-based control.
ISO 21500 gives context/concepts; ISO 21502 provides guidance and detailed management practices (clauses 7.x). High-level process/practice approach aligned to organizational governance.
Uses 'Performance Domains', 'Tailoring', 'Value Delivery System'. Modern, outcomes-focused language.
Uses 'Themes', 'Principles', 'Processes', 'Products'. British English and distinctive terminology.
Uses 'Subject Groups', 'Process Groups'. Neutral, internationally agreed terminology.

Describes organizational governance systems and functions associated with projects. Less prescriptive about job titles, more about functions and behaviors (principles-driven). Encourages tailoring of governance to context.

Strong governance model—explicit Project Board, project executive, clear accountabilities, manage-by-exception (tolerances) and directing-process. Prescribes named roles and the manage-by-exception mechanism.

Defines governance, governing body and project governance framework. Frames governance at organizational level (alignment with strategy and integrated governance). Clear Project Sponsor accountability.
Planning Performance Domain—supports multiple delivery cadences (predictive to adaptive). Planning variables, communication, metrics aligned to business case.
Product-based planning: Product Breakdown Structure and Product Flow Diagrams. Relationship between project/stage/team plans with stage boundaries.
Planning practice (7.2) plus dedicated clauses for schedule (7.6) and cost (7.7). Prescriptive clause-level guidance.
Fully integrated throughout. PMBOK 7 is methodology-agnostic, supporting predictive, adaptive, and hybrid.
PRINCE2 Agile is separate publication. Traditional PRINCE2 is predictive, though can be adapted.
Acknowledges different approaches but doesn't deeply integrate agile concepts.
Guideline and principles. Provides extensive techniques but doesn't mandate specific approach.
Method with defined processes, roles, and documents. More prescriptive structure.
High-level guidance. Most generic, intended for universal application.
Focus on value delivery and outcomes (system for value delivery). Business-case thinking embedded in principles. Treats benefits as part of the overall value-delivery system.

Business Case practice is central. Evolves through life cycle and is the basis for continued justification of the project. Lifecycle explicitly ties business case updates to stage boundaries and approvals.
Benefits management practice (7.3)—identify, analyse, monitor, maintain benefits in alignment with strategy. Provides structured benefit management activities.
Integrated across Planning & Project Work domains. Emphasizes adapting to cadence and stakeholders. Provides models and tailoring guidance.
Integrated into Organizing and Plans practices. Includes standard management products (highlight reports, checkpoint reports). Named report types and templates.
Communication management practice (7.13)—plan, distribute, monitor impact. Standard process steps for planning and reporting.
Procurement appears as part of Planning performance domain and Project Work considerations. Focus on procurement processes within project context.
Supplier side formalized (Senior Supplier role). Procurement integrated into organizing, plans and quality practices. Governance/role model assigns formal supplier representation and assurance roles.
Procurement management practice (7.17)—plan procurement, evaluate/select suppliers, administer and close contracts. Prescribes clause-level procurement steps.
Focus on outcomes and deliverables inside performance domains. Scope controlled within planning and project work. Outcome/value oriented.

Very product-focused—product descriptions drive scope, quality, acceptance. Product Breakdown Structure and Product Flow Diagrams are core techniques. Explicit 'product' artifacts central to planning.
Scope management as discrete practice (7.4)—define, control, confirm scope delivery. Standard processes for scope management.
Dedicated Measurement domain and Uncertainty domain (includes risk, complexity, ambiguity). Emphasizes outcomes-based measures. Provides performance-domain view and wider set of measures.
Progress practice with tolerance reporting, highlight/exception reports and metrics for stage control. Prescribes management products/reports and tolerances for exception handling.
Reporting (7.15) and guidance for monitoring project performance and reporting outputs. Maps reporting to standardized processes.
Addresses change across planning and project work. Tailoring determines specific control mechanisms. Leaves the specific mechanism to tailoring and the project's chosen approach.

Issues & change control practice—change proposals, issue registers, formal process for assessing/deciding on changes with clear responsibilities. Provides detailed roles and templates for issues/change handling.
Change control guidance (7.10)—establish framework, identify and assess change requests, plan implementation and closure. Provides clause-level steps to adopt.

unique.topic: Shift from process-based to principles-based standard
unique.description: Earlier editions of PMBOK, as well as PRINCE2 and ISO, were heavily process-oriented—focusing on sequences of activities and deliverables. The 7th Edition is unique because it abandons this rigid process view and instead defines 12 broad principles. These act as guiding philosophies (like stewardship, tailoring, stakeholder engagement) that can be applied flexibly to any type of project, traditional or agile.

unique.topic: Performance Domains instead of Knowledge Areas
unique.description: Instead of grouping content into knowledge areas (like scope, cost, schedule), it introduces eight performance domains (Stakeholder, Team, Development Approach, Delivery, Measurement, Uncertainty, etc.). These domains interact as a system of capabilities—something PRINCE2 and ISO don't emphasize. This systemic design is unique to PMBOK 7.

PMBOK 7 positions projects as not just internal efforts but as strategic drivers of value. The 'system for value delivery' connects projects to portfolios, programs, and operations—ensuring alignment with business strategy. This strategic systems view is unique compared to PRINCE2 (which is more about governance) and ISO (which focuses more on practices).

While all standards mention teams, PMBOK 7 uniquely dedicates an entire domain to how teams function. It discusses project culture, psychological safety, leadership approaches, and emotional intelligence in detail. It treats teams not just as 'resources' but as a living system that impacts outcomes.

Engagement isn't just a task here—it's both a principle (guiding philosophy for all projects) and a performance domain with its own success measures. The uniqueness is that PMBOK 7 makes relationship-building and co-creation with stakeholders central to project success, whereas PRINCE2 limits stakeholders to governance roles (Business, User, Supplier).

Other standards treat 'risk' as a standalone area. PMBOK 7 broadens this by embedding risk inside the Uncertainty Performance Domain, which also covers ambiguity, complexity, and volatility. This holistic framing is unique—it forces project managers to think beyond measurable risks and consider unknowns, systemic complexity, and change volatility.

Tailoring has always been encouraged, but PMBOK 7 makes it central and structured. It includes a full top-level section that explains how to tailor step-by-step: assess context, design governance, adapt practices. Neither PRINCE2 nor ISO gives tailoring this much structured attention. This makes tailoring one of PMBOK 7's defining unique elements.

Instead of prescribing one 'right' tool, PMBOK 7 provides a catalog-style toolkit of commonly used models (like servant leadership), methods (like Kanban), and artifacts (like risk registers). This flexible 'menu' approach is unique—it empowers practitioners to choose rather than follow a strict template.

PMBOK 7 is the only standard that connects directly to a digital, evolving platform (PMIstandards+). This ensures the content is not static but continually updated with practices, examples, and case studies. Neither PRINCE2 nor ISO offers this living knowledge base.

Unlike PMBOK or ISO, PRINCE2 organizes its guidance into five integrated elements: Principles, People, Practices, Processes, and Project Context. This is unique because 'People' has now been elevated as a separate core element acknowledging that leadership, teamwork, communication, and organizational relationships are just as fundamental as processes and principles.

PRINCE2 is unique for its clear step-by-step process model (e.g., 'Starting up a project,' 'Closing a project'). While PMBOK 7 moved away from prescriptive processes and ISO focuses on practices, PRINCE2 stands out for keeping a structured, linear process journey through the project lifecycle. This makes it especially appealing for organizations wanting strict control and repeatability.

PRINCE2 defines a governance structure with four layers: Commissioning, Directing, Managing, Delivering. This multilayered structure clarifies 'who does what' at every level of authority. Neither PMBOK nor ISO provides governance in such a layered form.

Unlike PMBOK 7 (broad stakeholder focus) or ISO (sponsor/customer perspective), PRINCE2 assigns three formal stakeholder roles on its Project Board: Business (ensures project remains viable), User (ensures project meets end-user needs), Supplier (ensures technical delivery is possible). This triad model of governance is unique to PRINCE2.

Uniquely, PRINCE2 treats sustainability as one of seven mandatory performance targets to manage, alongside cost, time, quality, benefits, risk, and scope. Neither PMBOK nor ISO elevate sustainability to this level of importance.

PRINCE2 combines change control and issue management into a single integrated practice called 'Issues,' with a 5-step structured technique. This unification is unique—ISO and PMBOK treat them separately.

PRINCE2 uniquely formalizes 16 required management products (documents such as the Business Case, Project Initiation Documentation). These products act as 'control points' for governance and decision-making. The newest edition even adds a Digital and Data Management Approach, which provides structured guidance for how digital tools and data will be managed throughout the project.

Uniquely defines project context in terms of commercial customer-supplier relationship, providing specific guidance on adapting roles, plans, and practices when formal commercial agreement or contract exists. PMBOK and ISO acknowledge contracts, but PRINCE2 integrates this directly into its method.

ISO 21502 uniquely divides its guidance into two categories: Integrated project management practices (covering the entire lifecycle) and Management practices for a project (specific functional areas). This dual-structure makes it easier to separate lifecycle guidance from specialized practices, something PMBOK and PRINCE2 don't do in the same way.

ISO 21502 uniquely formalizes what happens before and after a project: Pre-project ensures justification, feasibility, and organizational readiness; Post-project verifies sustainability of outcomes and benefits realization. PRINCE2 has a closure stage, and PMBOK discusses benefits, but neither standard formalizes pre/post activities as explicit lifecycle stages.

ISO 21502 provides a full governance framework that clarifies how projects should be authorized, directed, and controlled. It uniquely assigns clear accountability to the Project Sponsor for achieving objectives. While PRINCE2 and PMBOK mention sponsors, ISO makes sponsor accountability explicit and central.

Like PRINCE2, ISO 21502 recognizes customer-supplier relationships, but it does so differently: it emphasizes how governance and team structures should adapt when both parties are involved. This makes ISO 21502 broader and more adaptable across industries.

ISO 21502 is unique in explicitly including societal change (not just organizational change) as a management practice. This recognizes that some projects (government, infrastructure, public health) affect society at large and must consider long-term social impact. Neither PRINCE2 nor PMBOK frame change management this broadly.

ISO 21502 uniquely guides organizations on what to consider before even formalizing project management practices. It covers organizational maturity, readiness for structured governance, and the ability to absorb change. This is absent in PMBOK and PRINCE2, which assume the project environment already exists.

context.description: Well-defined requirements, <6 months duration, <7 team members
characteristics: Fixed timeline with aggressive delivery schedule (< 6 months)
Small, cross-functional team (5-7 members: PM, developers, QA, client rep)
Agile/iterative delivery preferred for rapid feedback
Moderate technical complexity with known technologies
context.tailoringRationale: This lightweight process combines governance clarity of PRINCE2 with PMBOK's flexibility and ISO 21502's feasibility validation, ensuring alignment before execution while maintaining agility.

keyActivities.description: Appointment of core roles (Project Manager, Developer, Client Representative, QA Lead).

references.note: PMBOK - Tailoring to context and system thinking

keyActivities.description: Definition of project objectives and success criteria aligned with organizational value delivery.
Formalization of a Business Case and feasibility confirmation.
Establishment of governance roles following PRINCE2's layered model (Business, User, Supplier) to ensure accountability and direction.

phases.name: 2. Planning Stage
phases.objective: Adaptive and iterative planning ensuring flexibility

keyActivities.description: Refinement of scope and deliverables using a rolling Product Backlog.
Definition of iteration cycles/timeboxes producing incremental software value.
Establishment of the Definition of Done (DoD) to embed quality expectations.
Development of the Project Initiation Documentation (PID) to define baselines for time, cost, and quality.

phases.name: 3. Execution Stage
phases.objective: Deliver working software through time-boxed iterations

keyActivities.description: Development and testing of functional increments from prioritized backlog items.
Application of PRINCE2's 'Manage by Exception' principle—time and cost fixed, scope flexible.
Ongoing validation and verification to ensure quality.
Maintenance of collaborative culture and stakeholder engagement.
Visualization of progress via Kanban or Task Boards.
Management of issues and change requests through PRINCE2's Issue and Change Practice.
Integration of feedback loops and retrospectives for adaptive planning.
Performance review against the original Business Case and PID.
Capture and dissemination of lessons learned.
Post-project evaluation for sustainability and long-term outcomes.

roles.description: Leads project execution, coordinates team, manages stakeholders
Designs, codes, and implements software solutions
Ensures quality standards and testing coverage
Represents business needs and validates deliverables

keyArtifacts.description: Documents project justification, objectives, and success criteria
Prioritized list of features and requirements
Documents completed work and stakeholder feedback

tailoringDecisions.rationale: Small team size allows for informal but clear governance structure
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: Less formal documentation, more reliance on team collaboration

tailoringDecisions.rationale: Ensures delivery momentum while adapting to changing requirements
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: May require scope negotiations with stakeholders

tailoringDecisions.rationale: Allows progressive elaboration as requirements become clearer

successFactors.importance: Critical for requirement clarity and acceptance

successFactors.mitigation: Daily standups and co-location when possible

successFactors.importance: Ensures early value and course correction

characteristics: High uncertainty and ambiguity in requirements
Need for adaptive approach and iterative refinement
context.tailoringRationale: High uncertainty requires strong initial governance before major investment decisions. Early business case development ensures continued viability, while tailoring the approach allows flexibility in managing evolving requirements.

phases.name: 1. Initiation Phase (P1: Initiation & Vision)
phases.objective: Establish governance, early control, and project vision

keyActivities.description: Appoint the Project Executive and Project Manager, and define the Project Management Team Structure. This establishes control and accountability early in the project lifecycle.
Develop the Outline Business Case and define a high-level scope through the Project Product Description, including acceptance criteria to frame early expectations.
Select a Hybrid/Adaptive Development Approach suited for research-driven environments. Establish initial Risk and Quality Management Approaches to prepare for controlled experimentation.

decisionGate.name: Decision Gate 1 – Authorize Initiation
criteria: Project Board authorizes initiation funding and resource commitment, ensuring alignment before detailed planning

keyActivities.description: Prepare detailed Stage Plans using Rolling Wave Planning. Refine R&D requirements into a Product Backlog and User Stories, progressively elaborated as uncertainty reduces.
Estimate work using uncertainty-based estimation techniques and update the Full Business Case to confirm continued viability and resource justification.

decisionGate.name: Decision Gate 2 – Authorize Next Stage
criteria: Project Board evaluates the End Stage Report and confirms that the project remains desirable, viable, and achievable

phases.name: 3. Execution Phase (P2: Iterative Delivery)
phases.objective: Develop and validate prototypes through iterations

keyActivities.description: Execute work in Timeboxes/Sprints, authorized as Work Packages. Deliver incremental outputs and a Minimum Viable Product (MVP) to test functionality and feasibility.
Apply Prototyping and Modeling to reduce technological uncertainty and complexity, enabling stakeholders to validate assumptions through tangible results.

decisionGate.name: Sprint Reviews
criteria: Iterative delivery balances innovation with control. Timeboxing fixes time and cost while allowing scope flexibility

keyActivities.description: Track progress using Kanban Boards and Checkpoint Reports. Apply Velocity Charts for performance measurement and adaptive planning.
Conduct ongoing Quality Control and Iteration Reviews. Capture insights in the Lessons Log for continuous improvement.

decisionGate.name: Continuous Control
criteria: Visual and adaptive controls enhance responsiveness while ensuring informed decision-making

keyActivities.description: Perform formal acceptance and quality control against the defined acceptance criteria. Update the Project Plan and confirm readiness for delivery.
Prepare transition to Business-as-Usual (BAU), updating the Benefits Management Approach to define post-project reviews and sustain value realization.

decisionGate.name: Decision Gate 3 – Authorize Final Transition
criteria: Project Board reviews End Stage Reports and approves transition to closure based on verified outcomes

keyActivities.description: Confirm all deliverables are completed.
Finalize the Lessons Report and transfer organizational assets and documentation for future use.

decisionGate.name: Decision Gate 4 – Project Closure Confirmation
criteria: Project Executive authorizes closure after evaluating performance and verifying benefits realization

roles.description: Senior decision maker with budget authority

tailoringDecisions.rationale: R&D uncertainty requires flexibility while maintaining governance

successFactors.mitigation: Regular communication of progress and learnings

context.description: Civil, electrical, and IT components, 2-year duration
context.tailoringRationale: PRINCE2's explicit governance roles are retained for accountability; PMBOK's principle-based initiation adds flexibility across civil, electrical, and IT domains; ISO guidance ensures alignment to statutory obligations.

phases.name: 1. Initiation Phase
phases.objective: Establish governance structure, strategic alignment, and feasibility

keyActivities.description: Identify project sponsors, steering committee, and key stakeholders.
Develop a Project Brief / Business Case.
Appoint the Project Board (Executive, Senior User, Senior Supplier) for formal oversight.
Conduct initial feasibility, environmental, and regulatory assessments.
Draft the high-level budget, procurement approach, and risk register.

decisionGate.name: Decision Gate 1: Business Case Approval
criteria: Business Case Approval by Project Board and Sponsor → proceed to Planning

phases.name: 2. Planning Phase
phases.objective: Define scope, budget, schedule, and compliance controls

keyActivities.description: Develop Product-Based Plans and Work Breakdown Structures.
Produce an integrated Master Schedule linking design, procurement, and construction.
Create Procurement Management Plan.
Establish Risk and Quality Management Plans.
Prepare Communication and Reporting Framework for stakeholders.

decisionGate.name: Decision Gate 2: PID Approval
criteria: PID Approval & Baseline Sign-off by Project Board

phases.name: 3. Execution Phase
phases.objective: Deliver outputs in controlled stages ensuring quality and compliance

keyActivities.description: Manage design, construction, and IT integration workstreams.
Conduct procurement and contract administration.
Perform quality inspections and system tests.
Monitor site safety, environment, and compliance.
Manage stakeholder engagement and communication cycles.

decisionGate.name: Decision Gate 3: Stage Completion
criteria: Stage Completion & Board Review — deliverables accepted, next stage authorized

phases.name: 4. Monitoring & Control Phase
phases.objective: Track performance, manage risk, ensure compliance

keyActivities.description: Maintain dashboards for cost, schedule, and risk.
Conduct periodic Stage Gate Reviews.
Implement formal Change Control Board decisions.
Update risk register and compliance reports.

decisionGate.name: Decision Gate 4: Change Control
criteria: Change Control and Stage Approval — authorize modifications or proceed to next milestone

keyActivities.description: Verify deliverables and regulatory compliance.
Conduct post-implementation review and lessons learned.
Confirm Business Case outcomes.
Archive documentation and release contracts/resources.

decisionGate.name: Decision Gate 5: Final Acceptance
criteria: Final Acceptance & Benefits Sign-off by Project Board and Sponsor

tailoringDecisions.rationale: Government projects require clear accountability and oversight
tailoringDecisions.tradeoffs: More formal documentation and approval processes

tailoringDecisions.rationale: Allows for controlled progress and decision points

successFactors.mitigation: Regular Project Board meetings and reporting
Dedicated compliance officer and regular audits
